I know exactly what the video maker meant.  I'm not arguing against him.

A sphere contains the most volume with the least amount of surface area.  What this means is that a sphere container can hold more water than a cube container made of the same amount of material.  More gas even.  More lentils.  But could a sphere container hold more common household items than a cubical?  Probably not, which is exactly my point.  I'm not trying to argue anything here, I'm simply making an observation that I think is quite ironic.

thye didn't necessarily mean a sphere was the most "effective" container, what the meant was a sphere is the most effective container of area in a volume, meaning if you have a square, a triangle, and a circle, and they all had the same area, the circle would have the least perimeter.

A sphere is the most efficient container, and yet, one of the least practical from an everyday life perspective.  Can you imagine spherical packing boxes?  Spherical lunchboxes?  I suppose the efficiency of a container is far more dependent on what it's containing than it's own form.

Rouleau engines are more efficient than regular piston driven ones. 

They also supposedly use less gas, and make less vibration.

Well I said they are like 2 stroke because in a wankel engine the injection, compression, ignition and exhaust all happen in the same cycle (one rotation of the piston). In a 4 stroke engine it happens in 2 cycles (4 strokes of the piston). Because in wankel engines the combustion happens in one cycle, it produces more power per cycle like a 2 stroke engine but is less efficient than a 4 stroke engine.
Round is not with constant with but with constant distance from its centre...

Rotaries aren't like 2-strokes, their more like a regular four stroke with twice the cylinders; they don't burn oil with fuel like a 2-stroke. Rotaries use oil with the apex seals to burn the least amount of fuel; 4-strokes also burn oil due to the nature of the seal, although not much, and it becomes more evident when they wear down.
Also going to catch you on a technicality there: vehicles which do use rotaries a lot are airplanes. Their light weight and "turbo-ability"(ha), is well received.

The Wankel rotor is not actually a Reuleaux Triangle. The flanks, or edges, of a Wankel Rotor are a little flatter to accommodate the compression chamber. If Felix was to have used a traditional Reuleaux Triangle, the  epitrochoid housing would have been more pronounced and probable take up a lot more room, not to mention a change in power delivery: it would most likely cause the engine to be far less awesome due to the altered compression/combustion chamber dimensions.
